articles.headline: Trump’s Trade Threats Hit China’s Stock Market and Currency
articles.snippet: China’s stock market has fallen into a bear market and the currency is tumbling on worries about tariffs and China’s efforts to rein in domestic debt.
articles.abstract: China’s stock market has fallen into a bear market and the currency is tumbling on worries about tariffs and China’s efforts to rein in domestic debt.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Months of struggling with economic problems at home and bickering with President Trump over trade are starting to take their toll on China’s financial health.

articles.headline: 5 People Dead in Shooting at Maryland’s Capital Gazette Newsroom
articles.snippet: The suspect, identified as Jarrod W. Ramos, 38, had a long history of conflict with the news group.
articles.abstract: The suspect, identified as Jarrod W. Ramos, 38, had a long history of conflict with the news group.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANNAPOLIS, Md. — A man armed with a shotgun and smoke grenades stormed into the newsroom of a community newspaper chain in Maryland’s capital on Thursday afternoon, killing five staff members, injuring two others and prompting law enforcement agencies across the country to provide protection at the headquarters of media organizations.
articles.byline: By Sabrina Tavernise, Amy Harmon and Maya Salam

articles.headline: Fighting Privilege: The Senate Finally Wants to Pay Its Interns
articles.snippet: In a bid to make Washington’s halls of power more diverse, the Senate is seeking to create a $5 million fund to compensate its interns, the first such organized congressional effort in two decades.
articles.abstract: In a bid to make Washington’s halls of power more diverse, the Senate is seeking to create a $5 million fund to compensate its interns, the first such organized congressional effort in two decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the past two years, DaQuawn Bruce received news — not once, but twice — that he had dreamed of since middle school. He had been accepted into two competitive internship programs on Capitol Hill, opportunities that swarms of students vie for every year.

articles.headline: Bank ‘Stress Tests’ Results Clear Way for Wall Street to Reward Investors
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve gave clean bills of health to top banks, but told Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley to freeze shareholder payouts at last year’s levels.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve gave clean bills of health to top banks, but told Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley to freeze shareholder payouts at last year’s levels.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve on Thursday gave clean bills of health to most of the largest American banks, allowing them to return money to shareholders, but it forced Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley to freeze such payouts around last year’s levels.
articles.byline: By Emily Flitter and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: California Passes Sweeping Law to Protect Online Privacy
articles.snippet: The attempt to provide regulatory oversight of the tech industry’s data collection is considered the most comprehensive in the nation.
articles.abstract: The attempt to provide regulatory oversight of the tech industry’s data collection is considered the most comprehensive in the nation.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — California has passed a digital privacy law granting consumers more control over and insight into the spread of their personal information online, creating one of the most significant regulations overseeing the data-collection practices of technology companies in the United States.

articles.headline: Inside the White House’s Quiet Campaign to Create a Supreme Court Opening
articles.snippet: Its goal was to assure Justice Anthony M. Kennedy that his judicial legacy would be in good hands should he decide to step down at the end of the court’s term.
articles.abstract: Its goal was to assure Justice Anthony M. Kennedy that his judicial legacy would be in good hands should he decide to step down at the end of the court’s term.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump singled him out for praise even while attacking other members of the Supreme Court. The White House nominated people close to him to important judicial posts. And members of the Trump family forged personal connections.
articles.byline: By Adam Liptak and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: In Meeting With Putin, Experts Fear Trump Will Give More Than He Gets
articles.snippet: Foreign policy officials, including some in his own administration, fear a repeat of President Trump’s encounter with Kim Jong-un, the North Korean leader.
articles.abstract: Foreign policy officials, including some in his own administration, fear a repeat of President Trump’s encounter with Kim Jong-un, the North Korean leader.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s appetite for a meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, his aides say, was whetted by his talks with Kim Jong-un, the leader of North Korea, two weeks ago. But it is precisely that encounter that is stirring unease among foreign policy experts, including some in his own administration.

articles.headline: This Is When the World Cup Surprises End. Usually.
articles.snippet: The carnival spirit and upsets of the World Cup’s group stage rarely continue in the knockout rounds, but international soccer is more democratic than ever.
articles.abstract: The carnival spirit and upsets of the World Cup’s group stage rarely continue in the knockout rounds, but international soccer is more democratic than ever.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — As Joachim Löw,  Germany's coach, considers all the things that went wrong for his team over the last two weeks, all the myriad factors that contributed to the reigning World Cup champion’s ignominious exit, one moment, in particular, will cause him to cringe.

articles.headline: A French Fry Gets Soggy in 5 Minutes. This Company Wants to Keep It Crispy for 60.
articles.snippet: Lamb Weston fires potatoes into metal blades at 75 miles per hour to make your fries. But when your delivery driver is slowed down by traffic, how will they hold up?
articles.abstract: Lamb Weston fires potatoes into metal blades at 75 miles per hour to make your fries. But when your delivery driver is slowed down by traffic, how will they hold up?
articles.lead_paragraph: The perfect French fry is crispy on the outside and fluffy on the inside.

articles.headline: China Taps the Brakes on Its Global Push for Influence
articles.snippet: Chinese companies are steering less money into its Belt and Road Initiative, as top officials ask whether borrowers will be able to repay loans.
articles.abstract: Chinese companies are steering less money into its Belt and Road Initiative, as top officials ask whether borrowers will be able to repay loans.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — China has spent nearly five years steering an ever-growing stream of hundreds of billions of dollars to a bold plan to gain greater global influence by funding big projects across Asia, Eastern Europe and Africa.
